contentrichtext.text: '''Susan Vera Cooper''', known as '''Susie Cooper''' (29 October 1902 â€“ 28 July 1995) was a prolific [[England|English]] [[ceramic]] designer working in the [[Stoke-on-Trent]] [[pottery]] industries from the 1920s to the 1980s.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/stoke/content/articles/2006/04/13/local_heroes_susie_cooper_01_feature.shtml|title=Local Heroes: Susie Cooper|work=BBC|date=13 April 2006|accessdate=14 April 2012}}</ref> ==Life and work== Born in Stanfields, Stoke-on-Trent, she was the youngest of seven children. From an early age she developed an interest in drawing, and began her art education by attending night classes at the [[Burslem School of Art]]. In 1922 she joined the ceramics firm [[Gray's Pottery|A.E. Gray & Co. Ltd]],<ref name=obituary>{{cite web|url=http://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/obituaries-susie-cooper-1594209.html|title=Obituaries: Susie Cooper|work=The Independent|date=1 August 1995|accessdate=14 April 2012}}</ref> partially as a means to gain entry to the [[Royal College of Art]]. A. Edward Gray quickly discovered her talents as a painter and designer, and soon enough Susie was producing her hand-painted floral designs. In 1923 A.E. Gray launched the Gloria Lustre Range employing the technique of [[lustreware]]. In 1929, motivated by her desire to design ceramic shapes in addition to decors, she broke away with her brother-in-law Albert "Jack" Beeson to set up her own business, as Susie Cooper Potteries. Susie worked for many other pottery firms over the next several decades, including [[Wedgwood]]. In 1940 she was awarded the [[Royal Designer for Industry]] by the [[Royal Society of Arts]],<ref name=obituary/> and in 1979 she received an [[Order of the British Empire|OBE]]. By all accounts [[Elizabeth Bowes-Lyon|Elizabeth, The Queen Mother]] was an admirer of her work. At the age of 80 she retired to live on the [[Isle of Man]], where she died in 1995. Like other [[Potteries]] based ceramic designers such as [[Clarice Cliff]] and [[Charlotte Rhead]], her work has become highly sought after and valued by pottery collectors. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.susiecooper.net/ Susie Cooper Information Site] biography, factory history, pottery marks. * [http://www.stoke.gov.uk/museums Stoke-on-Trent Museums] See Susie Cooper's designs plus the World's Finest Collection of Staffordshire Ceramics. * [http://www.search.exploringthepotteries.org.uk/engine/theme/default.asp?theme=594 Pots designed by Susie Cooper to explore online] * [http://www.grayspottery.co.uk/ Gray's pottery website] Resource website for Gray's Pottery {{Authority control|VIAF=35266600}} {{Persondata <!-- Metadata: see [[Wikipedia:Persondata]]. --> | NAME =Cooper, Susie | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = | DATE OF BIRTH = 29 October 1902 | PLACE OF BIRTH = [[Stoke-on-Trent]], [[United Kingdom]] | DATE OF DEATH = 28 July 1995 | PLACE OF DEATH = [[Douglas, Isle of Man]], [[Isle of Man]] }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Cooper, Susie}} [[Category:1902 births]] [[Category:1995 deaths]] [[Category:English potters]] [[Category:English ceramists]] [[Category:Alumni of the Royal College of Art]] [[Category:Dinnerware designers]] [[Category:People from Stoke-on-Trent]]
